Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Operating System based Energy Virtualization for Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: In recent years, wireless sensor networks have emerged as one key technology with the advantages of being low-cost, low-profile, and easy to deploy. These attractive advantages, however, imply that resources available to individual nodes are severely limited. In particular, it is highly likely that energy will continue to be a system bottleneck, as more transistors indicate more power consumption. On the other hand, there is a growing need for long-term, sustainable deployments of sensors to reduce operational costs and ensure service continuity. This research presents an operating system based approach and its underlying foundations for this problem, by providing energy virtualization in long-term unattended sensor network applications. The foundation of this work is the LiteOS operating system: a Unix-like operating system for wireless sensor networks. The centerpiece of this project is operating system based energy virtualization, which represents a comprehensive framework for accounting, reservation, and isolation of energy resource for applications sharing the same platform. The deliveries of this project are (i) an improved, highly reliable LiteOS operating system with built-in support for energy virtualization, (ii) architecture principles, design methodologies, programming APIs, and adaptive communication protocols for software development based on energy virtualization, (iii) results from theoretical and algorithmic investigations of energy virtualization, and (iv) educational testbeds, curriculum and laboratory designs for undergraduate and graduate courses. Our findings will have pervasive impact on applications that are in need of long-term and remote sensing, such as infrastructure protection, assisted living, smart buildings, factory monitoring, and numerous military applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated challenges related to networked sensors, which represent an emerging technology with the advantages of being low-cost, low-profile, and easy to deploy. One critical challenge we addressed was related to the fact that resources available to individual sensor nodes are severely limited. Furthermore, it is highly likely that energy will continue to be a system bottleneck, as more transistors indicate more power consumption. On the other hand, there is a growing need for long-term, sustainable, and robust deployments of sensors to reduce operational costs and ensure service continuity. This research presents a systematic solution for this problem, by proposing and developing an energy-efficient and robust programming and data analysis framework for long-term unattended sensor related applications. The centerpieces of this project include the following results:

1)   An energy virtualization framework that represents a comprehensive framework for accounting, reservation, and isolation of energy resource for applications sharing the same platform;

2)   A framework to improve the robustness of embedded software, where multiple methods, such as data mining, code replay, and dynamic instrumentation, have been developed for debugging and fault detection needs;

3)   Novel compact data structures and probabilistic methods for embedded platforms to further reduce energy cost in the level of algorithm designs, where multiple pieces of work, such as probabilistic bloom filters and key-value stores, have been developed;

4)   Principles and optimizations applied to modern mobile apps, where the results demonstrated energy benefits for app designs.

In broader impacts, we developed educational testbeds, curriculum and laboratory designs for undergraduate and graduate courses the PI taught. We disseminated the research work through multiple venues, such as conferences, workshops, invited talks, undergraduate seminars, and high school student summer courses. Research papers, tutorials, course materials, and labs have been developed and will continue to be used. 

On the education side, the work has involved multiple graduate students and undergraduate students. By closely interacting with them, the PI has helped the training of them as human resources for the area of computer science and engineering in general.  The project also involved high school students in the form of summer school programs. For example, in the summer of 2014, the PI interacted with four high school students through a summer course (four days). These high school students are mostly minority students, and this interaction exposed them with the state-of-the-art of computing in general, as well as inspiring them with STEM research topics for their future careers.
